utterances.translation: I am a descendent of _kinḥuuɬ_.

utterances.transcript: ʔuckʷiis kinḥuuɬ, ʔukčiiɬ kʷaatya, yaqukʷitii ɬuucma, kʷaatya ʔukɬaa.
utterances.translation: I am a descendent of _kinḥuuɬ_, who lived together with _kwaatya_, one who was his wife by the name of _kwaatya_.
They had children.
The oldest son was William Swan,
then my mother,

utterances.transcript: waa, ƛaʔuu yaqukʷitiis naʔiiqsu, Luke, [Luke Swan] , Roger ʔuʔukʷiɬʔanitʔišʔaaɬ ʔuušyuuya,
utterances.translation: and, also there was my uncle Luke Swan—sometimes people called him Roger.
and their youngest child, Alfons.
He had had a child (who is no longer alive).
_kinḥuuɬ_ was a Manhousaht chief.
He had the rights.
He owned the mountains.
Then there was another grandparent.
He was on my father’s side, by the name of _yuuwii_.
I briefly saw my grandparent, _yuuwii_.
His name was _č̓iḥtaap_.
He had another name.

utterances.transcript: histaqšiƛ ƛ̓ic̓aaʔatḥ, ƛ̓ic̓aaʔatḥ. yaqʔaƛ̓itq [James Adams] , [Carl Jumbo] .
utterances.translation: He was from _ƛ̓ic̓aaʔatḥ_ — from which James Adams and Carl Jumbo came.

utterances.transcript: haa qʷaaniiš. haa qʷaaniiš n̓uw̓iiqsakqs nananiqsakqs, kʷaatya, kinḥuuɬ yaqukʷitii ɬuucma, qiɬsmaʕaqsup, qiɬsmaʕaqsup.
utterances.translation: Yes, that is how we are (related)—my father, grandparents, _kwaatya_, wife of _kinḥuuɬ_, woman from Kelsomat.
So was the one whose name was _w̓iikinaniš_—he was from Kelsomat.

utterances.transcript: ʔaanaḥaƛ ʔin kʷaatya. naniiqsak, naniiqsakitq histaqšiƛ yaʕaƛ̓itqʔaɬ ʔačaq m̓ukʷina, m̓ukʷina. ʔaašaaštaqimɬ ʔukɬaa
utterances.translation: _kwaatya_′s grandparent was from the lineage of Maquinna—by the name of _ʔaašaaš_ clan.

utterances.transcript: čamiḥtackʷi ɬuucma, ḥakum waaʔat ḥakum waaʔatʔaaɬ
utterances.translation: She was an honorable woman. We call it _ḥakum_.
like a princess
I was born in winter, at the time when plants first grow.
It was snowing.

utterances.transcript: [month of February] , 1912 ʔuyimts, ʔuyickʷisa ʔaḥʔaa quʔiičiƛ
utterances.translation: Month of February, 1912—that’s when I was born.
And I grew up at Opnit.
For some years I grew up at Opnit
and then I went to _ʕaʔuknak_ to attend school.
I first went to _ʕaʔuknak_ in 1919.
This was when they first opened residential school.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥ hininyii, yaqukʷitiis naniiqsakqs yaqčhimitii, ʔiiqst̓a Louie.
utterances.translation: Then the one whom my grandfather married, _ʔiiqst̓a_ Louie, arrived.
She had got remarried.
I cried and cried.

transcript.en: I wanted to go with Jessie.

utterances.translation: I wanted to go with Jessie.
utterances.trs-en: I wanted to go with Jessie.

utterances.translation: They sent me home.
After some time I went back (to school).

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaƛ ʔaƛpuqʔičḥs school hiɬ, [7 years] , ʔaƛpuqʔičh.
utterances.translation: Then I attended school for seven years.
Many children had a hard time (at school)
(because) they didn’t understand (English).
I sort of understood (English) when I first went to school.
I understood what the teachers, principal and staff people were saying.
We weren’t allowed to talk (in our native language).

utterances.transcript: wikyaaminiš ƛ̓up̓iičḥaƛquu ʔacyuuʔaƛqin suuḥaa, ʔuʔuʔiiḥ cuw̓it,
utterances.translation: It (the ban on using the native language) didn’t have an effect on us during the summer, while we were out fishing for salmon, coho.
Sometimes we got cod

utterances.transcript: waa ʔaḥʔaaƛ ʕay̓iičḥ ʔaya muwač susaa, suusiɬaya
utterances.translation: and then in spring(?) many deer swam across.
That’s how we ate at _ʕaʔuknak_.
The steamboat would come every 10 days.
(They came) three times a month.
I finished (came out of) school in 1927.

utterances.transcript: ʔacyuu ?? ʔacyuu, fishing yaaqʷiɬʔitq mamaɬn̓i waa, kʷacinu hiistiɬ, ʔacyuu
utterances.translation: I was out fishing at Quatsiino

utterances.transcript: waa c̓uʔičḥ, č̓aastimc ʔuʔuʔiiḥ, saštup qʷaqʔiitq haptuup, waaxnii, ƛ̓iƛ̓iḥiy̓uuḥ, č̓aty̓a yaaqʷiɬʔitq waaʔat ƛapisum, racoon
utterances.translation: And during winter, I hunted for mink, other fur-bearing animals, otter, martin, raccon — which is called _ƛapisum_.
We never lack food to eat from low tide.
At low tides, we went digging clams.
We also went out hunting harbor seals.
Sometimes we caught deer.
We never went hungry.
We never ran out of things.
They very often fished for red snappers and _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_.
Red snappers are tastier than _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_.
They are like pitch gum. (They taste like pitch gum.)
This (the fact that _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_ tastes like pitch gum) is because _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_ is made of pitch gum.
Now I have started telling a story about what happened.

utterances.transcript: hiʔiisitwaʔiš ʔišc̓iipm̓it nism̓aʔi hiɬ ƛawaaquḥaa, ʔaɬmaʕa ʔukɬaa
utterances.translation: Son of Gum Woman lived at the place near _qaḥaa_, a place named _ʔaɬmaʕa_.
There were a lot of people in the village.
Son of Gum Woman got a wife.
He would go out fishing for red snapper.

utterances.transcript: ʔuyiʔisim ƛimksaap hupkʷistaʔaƛquu hupaɬ waa, hupkʷistaʔaƛquu hupaɬ
utterances.translation: He (Son of Gum Woman) said to her (his wife), “Wake me up when the sun is rising.”
The girl slept in.
Son of Gum Woman left in a canoe. [He started later than he planned because his wife didn’t wake him up early.]
“kwatkwatamiyaa yaa ?iishc’iipm’iit”
Now the sun is up and it got warm.
Son of Gum Woman went right through it (the heat).
He was gradually melting.
(And) he (finally) melted.
The canoe got capsized.
(Through this unfortunate incident) he ended up becoming _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_.
This is why _ʔiʔišpaaɬ_ tastes like pitch gum.
Its broth also tastes like pitch gum.
I side-tracked a little.
Now, some time elapsed.
The following year I did the same thing going back to the same place at Quatsino.
And then in 1930, there was no work.
There was absolutely no work. It was 1930.
I know how much we had in 1930.
I had 600 dollars, 1930.
I don’t know how much my late parents had.
It was snowing.
It was strange weather.
It was like that for a long time.
Then in 1940, it got better.
I ended up in a logging camp.

utterances.transcript: suučiƛ waa. suučiƛ. [Eight hours] , ʔaƛakʷaɬ. [Eight hours] qum̓aa.
utterances.translation: We worked for eight hours a day. (?)

utterances.transcript: ʕaciisḥ wiiqsiiʔaƛquu wik̓iit [time-off] logging, huuʔak ʔuyi
utterances.translation: Even in stormy weather there was no time off from logging a long time ago.
I became a union man.
And then again, we couldn’t get any fish for a while.
(And) that changed.
The following year there were so many.
We got many at Quatsino.

utterances.transcript: ʔaƛc̓iq, yaqukʷitiis naʔiiq [Luke Swan] , [John Campbell] , ʔuʔuqs
utterances.translation: There were two boats, my uncles Luke Swan and John Campbell, fishing.
We caught 2000 dog salmon — maybe it was 3000.
It wasn’t worth much.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaa ʔuuničhn̓ak čaanaat qiiyuuk̓ʷaɬs qaay̓uuk̓ʷatḥ hiɬ qii, [4 years]
utterances.translation: Then after some time, I went to Kyuquot for a long time — four years.
I worked at various places in Kyuquot. (?)

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaƛs huʔacačiƛ hiistanamʔaƛs Saballas t̓ašiis, [saw mill] ʔukʷiiɬna
utterances.translation: Then I went back and ended up at Saballas, Tahsis, and we made a sawmill.
It was a long time ago in 1945.
I worked with Gordon Gibson.

utterances.transcript: ʔunaakitʔiš miɬɬ, [Gordon Gibson] , [Matilda Creek] , ʕaaḥuusʔatḥ hiɬ
utterances.translation: Gordon Gibson owned the mill on the Matilda Creek in Ahousat.
We worked in February.
Although it was in winter and cold, we worked.
An east wind was blowing and it was snowing.
It took six months to finish the mill.
I said to Gordon, “For now, I’m going out fishing.”
I was on a boat with my younger brother (Phillip).

utterances.transcript: nasaƛs waaʔaƛ, nasaƛs [I can̓t get any fish] waa
utterances.translation: He (Phillip) said “I can’t get any fish.”

utterances.transcript: qiičiʔaƛs suutiɬ ḥaaḥuupa Phillip waaʔaƛs. qiičiʔaƛs suutiɬ ḥaaḥuupa
utterances.translation: I said to Phillip, “I have been teaching you (how to fish) for a long time.”

utterances.transcript: naʔuuk ʔacšiƛna ʔayaaƛ suuḥaa Juɬy ʔuyi August ʔaya
utterances.translation: We went along fishing plenty of salmon in July and August.
Then after a while the season for dog salmon ended.
George Sye said to me, “You will come along with me.
We will fish herring.”
We went fishing, but we couldn’t get any at first.
We would barely get 50, 60 ton.
(But) it (the amount of fish we got) increased and became plenty — we were catching many.
It would reach 100 ton, sometimes 150.
Once we netted a big load.
George Sye got 750 ton.
All the tender boats became full.
Women were working (busy cleaning fish)
and then I went home.
For now I went home. I went back to Ahousaht.
I stayed home for a long time.
“Let’s move to a different place,” Viola said to me.
We went to Port Alberni.
We were at Port Alberni for seven years.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaƛs, yaqukʷiis ʔaasiiqsu waɬaak̓i p̓aačiina waaʔaƛ̓ats č̓aapaciiɬw̓it̓as
utterances.translation: Then my niece said to me, “Go to Pachina and to make a canoe.”
I was in Pachina for six months making a canoe.

utterances.transcript: hiɬʔaƛ̓iš ƛaḥ č̓apacʔi [Wiikinanash Lodge] . hiiɬʔaƛ̓iš ʔaḥʔaa.
utterances.translation: Now the canoe is placed in the Wiikinanash lodge. It is put there.
I got a call from Toronto [asking me to go there to build a canoe].
I said “alright”.
In the month of June I went to Toronto.
I completed a canoe.

utterances.transcript: [3 months] hiɬs Toronto ƛ̓up̓iičḥ, [during the summer time]
utterances.translation: I was in Toronto for three months during the summer.

utterances.transcript: hiniic ʔaƛa qacc̓a t̓aatn̓a, waa kʷaʔuuc ɬuucmaakqs
utterances.translation: I took two, three children, a grandchild, and my wife.
Toronto used to be hot, a hot place.
I would work early.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaƛs ʔaḥ huḥtakšiƛ ʔin ʔucuk nanaʔat, huḥtakmaḥsatquu,
utterances.translation: Then I realized that it was necessary to be educated — I wanted to study.
That was when I went to University of Victoria.
I majored in anthropology. (?)
I wasn’t retired yet.
I finished University of Victoria in 10 years.
Then I went to Denmark for a while in ’85.
Then I graduated in 1987.
I took it from there to be here.
I finally finished University.
I have been working for the Royal Museum.
I have been working there for six years.
And during the winter I have been working with Tom Hess.
During summer, (I have been working with) a couple.
First Toshi was alone.
Toshi came alone.
I have got a friend, Toshi said to me.

transcript.en: Toshi said I’ve got a girlfriend.

utterances.translation: Toshi said I’ve got a girlfriend.
utterances.trs-en: Toshi said I’ve got a girlfriend.

utterances.translation: “Oh, I see,” I said to Toshi.
“You are doing the right thing.”
The following year, the two came.
Toshi came with another person, his wife. They were two.
And they still came together.
I think this is the third year.
This is the third year.
It has been two years for his wife.
I have known Toshi and his wife for three years.

utterances.transcript: waa ʔaya mamaɬn̓i, ƛaƛuu huuḥtakšiiḥmaḥsa language
utterances.translation: Many white people and others want to learn our language.
That’s what I am doing — teaching (them our language).
I don’t teach dirty language.

utterances.transcript: ʔana ʔančiɬs ʔiiqḥuk qʷiqʔiitq ƛuɬ, ƛuɬmis
utterances.translation: I only tell good words.
There are many things that should be kept private.
Whatever is private is called _qaanim_.

utterances.transcript: yaaqʷiɬʔitq [private parts of our body] qaan̓im waanaa
utterances.translation: We call our private parts of our body _qaanim_.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaa, hiišiɬsa huḥtak ʕaaʕimt̓at ʔusit̓atqin ʔuničiƛqin, hiist̓iƛ t̓uḥc̓iti, hapsy̓up hapcaasqi ḥuuɬ ƛišƛin, č̓ič̓isaqḥtim waaʔat č̓aɬč̓a, hišuk č̓aɬč̓a
utterances.translation: I know the names of different parts of our body — the whole body, starting from our head and head hair, to feet, toes, nails, all nails.
Nails on toes are also called _č̓aɬč̓a_.
And those on the hands are also called _č̓aɬč̓a_.
That’s the end. I only took a little bit of my life.
